segment.source: Security identifiers (Windows 10)
segment.target: Security identifiers (Windows 10)

segment.source: Security identifiers
segment.target: Security identifiers

segment.source: Security identifiers
segment.target: Security identifiers

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: This topic for the IT professional describes security identifiers and how they work in regards to accounts and groups in the Windows operating system.
segment.target: This topic for the IT professional describes security identifiers and how they work in regards to accounts and groups in the Windows operating system.

segment.source: What are security identifiers?
segment.target: What are security identifiers?

segment.source: A security identifier (SID) is used to uniquely identify a security principal or security group.
segment.target: A security identifier (SID) is used to uniquely identify a security principal or security group.

segment.source: Security principals can represent any entity that can be authenticated by the operating system, such as a user account, a computer account, or a thread or process that runs in the security context of a user or computer account.
segment.target: Security principals can represent any entity that can be authenticated by the operating system, such as a user account, a computer account, or a thread or process that runs in the security context of a user or computer account.

segment.source: Each account or group, or process running in the security context of the account, has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as a Windows domain controller.
segment.target: Each account or group, or process running in the security context of the account, has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as a Windows domain controller.

segment.source: It is stored in a security database.
segment.target: It is stored in a security database.

segment.source: The system generates the SID that identifies a particular account or group at the time the account or group is created.
segment.target: The system generates the SID that identifies a particular account or group at the time the account or group is created.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it can never be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it can never be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: Each time a user signs in, the system creates an access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user signs in, the system creates an access token for that user.

segment.source: The access token contains the user's SID, user rights, and the SIDs for any groups the user belongs to.
segment.target: The access token contains the user's SID, user rights, and the SIDs for any groups the user belongs to.

segment.source: This token provides the security context for whatever actions the user performs on that computer.
segment.target: This token provides the security context for whatever actions the user performs on that computer.

segment.source: In addition to the uniquely created, domain-specific SIDs that are assigned to specific users and groups, there are well-known SIDs that identify generic groups and generic users.
segment.target: In addition to the uniquely created, domain-specific SIDs that are assigned to specific users and groups, there are well-known SIDs that identify generic groups and generic users.

segment.source: For example, the Everyone and World SIDs identify a group that includes all users.
segment.target: For example, the Everyone and World SIDs identify a group that includes all users.

segment.source: Well-known SIDs have values that remain constant across all operating systems.
segment.target: Well-known SIDs have values that remain constant across all operating systems.

segment.source: SIDs are a fundamental building block of the Windows security model.
segment.target: SIDs are a fundamental building block of the Windows security model.

segment.source: They work with specific components of the authorization and access control technologies in the security infrastructure of the Windows Server operating systems.
segment.target: They work with specific components of the authorization and access control technologies in the security infrastructure of the Windows Server operating systems.

segment.source: This helps protect access to network resources and provides a more secure computing environment.
segment.target: This helps protect access to network resources and provides a more secure computing environment.

segment.source: The content in this topic applies to computers that are running the supported versions of the Windows operating system as designated in the Applies To list at the beginning of this topic.
segment.target: The content in this topic applies to computers that are running the supported versions of the Windows operating system as designated in the Applies To list at the beginning of this topic.

segment.source: How security identifiers work
segment.target: How security identifiers work

segment.source: Users refer to accounts by using the account name, but the operating system internally refers to accounts and processes that run in the security context of the account by using their security identifiers (SIDs).
segment.target: Users refer to accounts by using the account name, but the operating system internally refers to accounts and processes that run in the security context of the account by using their security identifiers (SIDs).

segment.source: For domain accounts, the SID of a security principal is created by concatenating the SID of the domain with a relative identifier (RID) for the account.
segment.target: For domain accounts, the SID of a security principal is created by concatenating the SID of the domain with a relative identifier (RID) for the account.

segment.source: SIDs are unique within their scope (domain or local), and they are never reused.
segment.target: SIDs are unique within their scope (domain or local), and they are never reused.

segment.source: The operating system generates a SID that identifies a particular account or group at the time the account or group is created.
segment.target: The operating system generates a SID that identifies a particular account or group at the time the account or group is created.

segment.source: The SID for a local account or group is generated by the Local Security Authority (LSA) on the computer, and it is stored with other account information in a secure area of the registry.
segment.target: The SID for a local account or group is generated by the Local Security Authority (LSA) on the computer, and it is stored with other account information in a secure area of the registry.

segment.source: The SID for a domain account or group is generated by the domain security authority, and it is stored as an attribute of the User or Group object in Active Directory Domain Services.
segment.target: The SID for a domain account or group is generated by the domain security authority, and it is stored as an attribute of the User or Group object in Active Directory Domain Services.

segment.source: For every local account and group, the SID is unique for the computer where it was created.
segment.target: For every local account and group, the SID is unique for the computer where it was created.

segment.source: No two accounts or groups on the computer ever share the same SID.
segment.target: No two accounts or groups on the computer ever share the same SID.

segment.source: Likewise, for every domain account and group, the SID is unique within an enterprise.
segment.target: Likewise, for every domain account and group, the SID is unique within an enterprise.

segment.source: This means that the SID for an account or group that is created in one domain will never match the SID for an account or group created in any other domain in the enterprise.
segment.target: This means that the SID for an account or group that is created in one domain will never match the SID for an account or group created in any other domain in the enterprise.

segment.source: SIDs always remain unique.
segment.target: SIDs always remain unique.

segment.source: Security authorities never issue the same SID twice, and they never reuse SIDs for deleted accounts.
segment.target: Security authorities never issue the same SID twice, and they never reuse SIDs for deleted accounts.

segment.source: For example, if a user with a user account in a Windows domain leaves her job, an administrator deletes her Active Directory account, including the SID that identifies the account.
segment.target: For example, if a user with a user account in a Windows domain leaves her job, an administrator deletes her Active Directory account, including the SID that identifies the account.

segment.source: If she later returns to a different job at the same company, an administrator creates a new account, and the Windows Server operating system generates a new SID.
segment.target: If she later returns to a different job at the same company, an administrator creates a new account, and the Windows Server operating system generates a new SID.

segment.source: The new SID does not match the old one; so none of the user's access from her old account is transferred to the new account.
segment.target: The new SID does not match the old one; so none of the user's access from her old account is transferred to the new account.

segment.source: Her two accounts represent two completely different security principals.
segment.target: Her two accounts represent two completely different security principals.

segment.source: Security identifier architecture
segment.target: Security identifier architecture

segment.source: A security identifier is a data structure in binary format that contains a variable number of values.
segment.target: A security identifier is a data structure in binary format that contains a variable number of values.

segment.source: The first values in the structure contain information about the SID structure.
segment.target: The first values in the structure contain information about the SID structure.

segment.source: The remaining values are arranged in a hierarchy (similar to a telephone number), and they identify the SID-issuing authority (for example, the Windows Server 2012 operating system), the SID-issuing domain, and a particular security principal or group.
segment.target: The remaining values are arranged in a hierarchy (similar to a telephone number), and they identify the SID-issuing authority (for example, the Windows Server 2012 operating system), the SID-issuing domain, and a particular security principal or group.

segment.source: The following image illustrates the structure of a SID.
segment.target: The following image illustrates the structure of a SID.

segment.source: The individual values of a SID are described in the following table.
segment.target: The individual values of a SID are described in the following table.

segment.source: Comment
segment.target: Comment

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Revision
segment.target: Revision

segment.source: Indicates the version of the SID structure that is used in a particular SID.
segment.target: Indicates the version of the SID structure that is used in a particular SID.

segment.source: Identifier authority
segment.target: Identifier authority

segment.source: Identifies the highest level of authority that can issue SIDs for a particular type of security principal.
segment.target: Identifies the highest level of authority that can issue SIDs for a particular type of security principal.

segment.source: For example, the identifier authority value in the SID for the Everyone group is 1 (World Authority).
segment.target: For example, the identifier authority value in the SID for the Everyone group is 1 (World Authority).

segment.source: The identifier authority value in the SID for a specific Windows Server account or group is 5 (NT Authority).
segment.target: The identifier authority value in the SID for a specific Windows Server account or group is 5 (NT Authority).

segment.source: Subauthorities
segment.target: Subauthorities

segment.source: >Holds the most important information in a SID, which is contained in a series of one or more subauthority values.
segment.target: >Holds the most important information in a SID, which is contained in a series of one or more subauthority values.

segment.source: All values up to, but not including, the last value in the series collectively identify a domain in an enterprise.
segment.target: All values up to, but not including, the last value in the series collectively identify a domain in an enterprise.

segment.source: This part of the series is called the domain identifier.
segment.target: This part of the series is called the domain identifier.

segment.source: The last value in the series, which is called the relative identifier (RID), identifies a particular account or group relative to a domain.
segment.target: The last value in the series, which is called the relative identifier (RID), identifies a particular account or group relative to a domain.

segment.source: The components of a SID are easier to visualize when SIDs are converted from a binary to a string format by using standard notation:
segment.target: The components of a SID are easier to visualize when SIDs are converted from a binary to a string format by using standard notation:

segment.source: In this notation, the components of a SID are represented as shown in the following table.
segment.target: In this notation, the components of a SID are represented as shown in the following table.

segment.source: Comment
segment.target: Comment

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: S
segment.target: S

segment.source: Indicates that the string is a SID
segment.target: Indicates that the string is a SID

segment.source: R
segment.target: R

segment.source: Indicates the revision level
segment.target: Indicates the revision level

segment.source: X
segment.target: X

segment.source: Indicates the identifier authority value
segment.target: Indicates the identifier authority value

segment.source: Y
segment.target: Y

segment.source: Represents a series of subauthority values, where n is the number of values
segment.target: Represents a series of subauthority values, where n is the number of values

segment.source: The SID's most important information is contained in the series of subauthority values.
segment.target: The SID's most important information is contained in the series of subauthority values.

segment.source: The first part of the series (-Y1-Y2-Yn-1) is the domain identifier.
segment.target: The first part of the series (-Y1-Y2-Yn-1) is the domain identifier.

segment.source: This element of the SID becomes significant in an enterprise with several domains, because the domain identifier differentiates SIDs that are issued by one domain from SIDs that are issued by all other domains in the enterprise.
segment.target: This element of the SID becomes significant in an enterprise with several domains, because the domain identifier differentiates SIDs that are issued by one domain from SIDs that are issued by all other domains in the enterprise.

segment.source: No two domains in an enterprise share the same domain identifier.
segment.target: No two domains in an enterprise share the same domain identifier.

segment.source: The last item in the series of subauthority values (-Yn) is the relative identifier.
segment.target: The last item in the series of subauthority values (-Yn) is the relative identifier.

segment.source: It distinguishes one account or group from all other accounts and groups in the domain.
segment.target: It distinguishes one account or group from all other accounts and groups in the domain.

segment.source: No two accounts or groups in any domain share the same relative identifier.
segment.target: No two accounts or groups in any domain share the same relative identifier.

segment.source: For example, the SID for the built-in Administrators group is represented in standardized SID notation as the following string:
segment.target: For example, the SID for the built-in Administrators group is represented in standardized SID notation as the following string:

segment.source: This SID has four components:
segment.target: This SID has four components:

segment.source: A revision level (1)
segment.target: A revision level (1)

segment.source: An identifier authority value (5, NT Authority)
segment.target: An identifier authority value (5, NT Authority)

segment.source: A domain identifier (32, Builtin)
segment.target: A domain identifier (32, Builtin)

segment.source: A relative identifier (544, Administrators)
segment.target: A relative identifier (544, Administrators)

segment.source: SIDs for built-in accounts and groups always have the same domain identifier value: 32.
segment.target: SIDs for built-in accounts and groups always have the same domain identifier value: 32.

segment.source: This value identifies the domain Builtin, which exists on every computer that is running a version of the Windows Server operating system.
segment.target: This value identifies the domain Builtin, which exists on every computer that is running a version of the Windows Server operating system.

segment.source: It is never necessary to distinguish one computer's built-in accounts and groups from another computer's built-in accounts and groups because they are local in scope.
segment.target: It is never necessary to distinguish one computer's built-in accounts and groups from another computer's built-in accounts and groups because they are local in scope.

segment.source: They are local to a single computer, or in the case of domain controllers for a network domain, they are local to several computers that are acting as one.
segment.target: They are local to a single computer, or in the case of domain controllers for a network domain, they are local to several computers that are acting as one.

segment.source: Built-in accounts and groups need to be distinguished from one another within the scope of the Builtin domain.
segment.target: Built-in accounts and groups need to be distinguished from one another within the scope of the Builtin domain.

segment.source: Therefore, the SID for each account and group has a unique relative identifier.
segment.target: Therefore, the SID for each account and group has a unique relative identifier.

segment.source: A relative identifier value of 544 is unique to the built-in Administrators group.
segment.target: A relative identifier value of 544 is unique to the built-in Administrators group.

segment.source: No other account or group in the Builtin domain has a SID with a final value of 544.
segment.target: No other account or group in the Builtin domain has a SID with a final value of 544.

segment.source: In another example, consider the SID for the global group, Domain Admins.
segment.target: In another example, consider the SID for the global group, Domain Admins.

segment.source: Every domain in an enterprise has a Domain Admins group, and the SID for each group is different.
segment.target: Every domain in an enterprise has a Domain Admins group, and the SID for each group is different.

segment.source: The following example represents the SID for the Domain Admins group in the Contoso, Ltd.
segment.target: The following example represents the SID for the Domain Admins group in the Contoso, Ltd.

segment.source: domain (ContosoDomain Admins):
segment.target: domain (ContosoDomain Admins):

segment.source: The SID for ContosoDomain Admins has:
segment.target: The SID for ContosoDomain Admins has:

segment.source: A revision level (1)
segment.target: A revision level (1)

segment.source: An identifier authority (5, NT Authority)
segment.target: An identifier authority (5, NT Authority)

segment.source: A relative identifier (512, Domain Admins)
segment.target: A relative identifier (512, Domain Admins)

segment.source: The SID for ContosoDomain Admins is distinguished from the SIDs for other Domain Admins groups in the same enterprise by its domain identifier: 21-1004336348-1177238915-682003330.
segment.target: The SID for ContosoDomain Admins is distinguished from the SIDs for other Domain Admins groups in the same enterprise by its domain identifier: 21-1004336348-1177238915-682003330.

segment.source: No other domain in the enterprise uses this value as its domain identifier.
segment.target: No other domain in the enterprise uses this value as its domain identifier.

segment.source: The SID for ContosoDomain Admins is distinguished from the SIDs for other accounts and groups that are created in the Contoso domain by its relative identifier, 512.
segment.target: The SID for ContosoDomain Admins is distinguished from the SIDs for other accounts and groups that are created in the Contoso domain by its relative identifier, 512.

segment.source: No other account or group in the domain has a SID with a final value of 512.
segment.target: No other account or group in the domain has a SID with a final value of 512.

segment.source: Relative identifier allocation
segment.target: Relative identifier allocation

segment.source: When accounts and groups are stored in an account database that is managed by a local Security Accounts Manager (SAM), it is fairly easy for the system to generate a unique relative identifier for each account and in a group that it creates on a stand-alone computer.
segment.target: When accounts and groups are stored in an account database that is managed by a local Security Accounts Manager (SAM), it is fairly easy for the system to generate a unique relative identifier for each account and in a group that it creates on a stand-alone computer.

segment.source: The SAM on a stand-alone computer can track the relative identifier values that it has used before and make sure that it never uses them again.
segment.target: The SAM on a stand-alone computer can track the relative identifier values that it has used before and make sure that it never uses them again.

segment.source: In a network domain, however, generating unique relative identifiers is a more complex process.
segment.target: In a network domain, however, generating unique relative identifiers is a more complex process.

segment.source: Windows Server network domains can have several domain controllers.
segment.target: Windows Server network domains can have several domain controllers.

segment.source: Each domain controller stores Active Directory account information.
segment.target: Each domain controller stores Active Directory account information.

segment.source: This means that, in a network domain, there are as many copies of the account database as there are domain controllers.
segment.target: This means that, in a network domain, there are as many copies of the account database as there are domain controllers.

segment.source: In addition to this, every copy of the account database is a master copy.
segment.target: In addition to this, every copy of the account database is a master copy.

segment.source: New accounts and groups can be created on any domain controller.
segment.target: New accounts and groups can be created on any domain controller.

segment.source: Changes that are made to Active Directory on one domain controller are replicated to all other domain controllers in the domain.
segment.target: Changes that are made to Active Directory on one domain controller are replicated to all other domain controllers in the domain.

segment.source: The process of replicating changes in one master copy of the account database to all other master copies is called a multimaster operation.
segment.target: The process of replicating changes in one master copy of the account database to all other master copies is called a multimaster operation.

segment.source: The process of generating unique relative identifiers is a single-master operation.
segment.target: The process of generating unique relative identifiers is a single-master operation.

segment.source: One domain controller is assigned the role of relative identifier (RID) master, and it allocates a sequence of relative identifiers to each domain controller in the domain.
segment.target: One domain controller is assigned the role of relative identifier (RID) master, and it allocates a sequence of relative identifiers to each domain controller in the domain.

segment.source: When a new domain account or group is created in one domain controller's replica of Active Directory, it is assigned a SID.
segment.target: When a new domain account or group is created in one domain controller's replica of Active Directory, it is assigned a SID.

segment.source: The relative identifier for the new SID is taken from the domain controller's allocation of relative identifiers.
segment.target: The relative identifier for the new SID is taken from the domain controller's allocation of relative identifiers.

segment.source: When its supply of relative identifiers begins to run low, the domain controller requests another block from the RID master.
segment.target: When its supply of relative identifiers begins to run low, the domain controller requests another block from the RID master.

segment.source: Each domain controller uses each value in a block of relative identifiers only once.
segment.target: Each domain controller uses each value in a block of relative identifiers only once.

segment.source: The RID master allocates each block of relative identifier values only once.
segment.target: The RID master allocates each block of relative identifier values only once.

segment.source: This process assures that every account and group created in the domain has a unique relative identifier.
segment.target: This process assures that every account and group created in the domain has a unique relative identifier.

segment.source: Security identifiers and globally unique identifiers
segment.target: Security identifiers and globally unique identifiers

segment.source: When a new domain user or group account is created, Active Directory stores the account's SID in the ObjectSID property of a User or Group object.
segment.target: When a new domain user or group account is created, Active Directory stores the account's SID in the ObjectSID property of a User or Group object.

segment.source: It also assigns the new object a globally unique identifier (GUID), which is a 128-bit value that is unique not only in the enterprise, but also across the world.
segment.target: It also assigns the new object a globally unique identifier (GUID), which is a 128-bit value that is unique not only in the enterprise, but also across the world.

segment.source: GUIDs are assigned to every object that is created by Active Directory, not only User and Group objects.
segment.target: GUIDs are assigned to every object that is created by Active Directory, not only User and Group objects.

segment.source: Each object's GUID is stored in its ObjectGUID property.
segment.target: Each object's GUID is stored in its ObjectGUID property.

segment.source: Active Directory uses GUIDs internally to identify objects.
segment.target: Active Directory uses GUIDs internally to identify objects.

segment.source: For example, the GUID is one of an object's properties that is published in the global catalog.
segment.target: For example, the GUID is one of an object's properties that is published in the global catalog.

segment.source: Searching the global catalog for a User object GUID produces results if the user has an account somewhere in the enterprise.
segment.target: Searching the global catalog for a User object GUID produces results if the user has an account somewhere in the enterprise.

segment.source: In fact, searching for any object by ObjectGUID might be the most reliable way of finding the object you want to locate.
segment.target: In fact, searching for any object by ObjectGUID might be the most reliable way of finding the object you want to locate.

segment.source: The values of other object properties can change, but the ObjectGUID property never changes.
segment.target: The values of other object properties can change, but the ObjectGUID property never changes.

segment.source: When an object is assigned a GUID, it keeps that value for life.
segment.target: When an object is assigned a GUID, it keeps that value for life.

segment.source: If a user moves from one domain to another, the user gets a new SID.
segment.target: If a user moves from one domain to another, the user gets a new SID.

segment.source: The SID for a group object does not change because groups stay in the domain where they were created.
segment.target: The SID for a group object does not change because groups stay in the domain where they were created.

segment.source: However, if people move, their accounts can move with them.
segment.target: However, if people move, their accounts can move with them.

segment.source: If an employee moves from North America to Europe, but stays in the same company, an administrator for the enterprise can move the employee's User object from, for example, ContosoNoAm to ContosoEurope.
segment.target: If an employee moves from North America to Europe, but stays in the same company, an administrator for the enterprise can move the employee's User object from, for example, ContosoNoAm to ContosoEurope.

segment.source: If the administrator does this, the User object for the account needs a new SID.
segment.target: If the administrator does this, the User object for the account needs a new SID.

segment.source: The domain identifier portion of a SID that is issued in NoAm is unique to NoAm; so the SID for the user's account in Europe has a different domain identifier.
segment.target: The domain identifier portion of a SID that is issued in NoAm is unique to NoAm; so the SID for the user's account in Europe has a different domain identifier.

segment.source: The relative identifier portion of a SID is unique relative to the domain; so if the domain changes, the relative identifier also changes.
segment.target: The relative identifier portion of a SID is unique relative to the domain; so if the domain changes, the relative identifier also changes.

segment.source: When a User object moves from one domain to another, a new SID must be generated for the user account and stored in the ObjectSID property.
segment.target: When a User object moves from one domain to another, a new SID must be generated for the user account and stored in the ObjectSID property.

segment.source: Before the new value is written to the property, the previous value is copied to another property of a User object, SIDHistory.
segment.target: Before the new value is written to the property, the previous value is copied to another property of a User object, SIDHistory.

segment.source: This property can hold multiple values.
segment.target: This property can hold multiple values.

segment.source: Each time a User object moves to another domain, a new SID is generated and stored in the ObjectSID property, and another value is added to the list of old SIDs in SIDHistory.
segment.target: Each time a User object moves to another domain, a new SID is generated and stored in the ObjectSID property, and another value is added to the list of old SIDs in SIDHistory.

segment.source: When a user signs in and is successfully authenticated, the domain authentication service queries Active Directory for all the SIDs that are associated with the user, including the user's current SID, the user's old SIDs, and the SIDs for the user's groups.
segment.target: When a user signs in and is successfully authenticated, the domain authentication service queries Active Directory for all the SIDs that are associated with the user, including the user's current SID, the user's old SIDs, and the SIDs for the user's groups.

segment.source: All these SIDs are returned to the authentication client, and they are included in the user's access token.
segment.target: All these SIDs are returned to the authentication client, and they are included in the user's access token.

segment.source: When the user tries to gain access to a resource, any one of the SIDs in the access token (including one of the SIDs in SIDHistory), can allow or deny the user access.
segment.target: When the user tries to gain access to a resource, any one of the SIDs in the access token (including one of the SIDs in SIDHistory), can allow or deny the user access.

segment.source: If you allow or deny users' access to a resource based on their jobs, you should allow or deny access to a group, not to an individual.
segment.target: If you allow or deny users' access to a resource based on their jobs, you should allow or deny access to a group, not to an individual.

segment.source: That way, when users change jobs or move to other departments, you can easily adjust their access by removing them from certain groups and adding them to others.
segment.target: That way, when users change jobs or move to other departments, you can easily adjust their access by removing them from certain groups and adding them to others.

segment.source: However, if you allow or deny an individual user access to resources, you probably want that user's access to remain the same no matter how many times the user's account domain changes.
segment.target: However, if you allow or deny an individual user access to resources, you probably want that user's access to remain the same no matter how many times the user's account domain changes.

segment.source: The SIDHistory property makes this possible.
segment.target: The SIDHistory property makes this possible.

segment.source: When a user changes domains, there is no need to change the access control list (ACL) on any resource.
segment.target: When a user changes domains, there is no need to change the access control list (ACL) on any resource.

segment.source: If an ACL has the user's old SID, but not the new one, the old SID is still in the user's access token.
segment.target: If an ACL has the user's old SID, but not the new one, the old SID is still in the user's access token.

segment.source: It is listed among the SIDs for the user's groups, and the user is granted or denied access based on the old SID.
segment.target: It is listed among the SIDs for the user's groups, and the user is granted or denied access based on the old SID.

segment.source: Well-known SIDs
segment.target: Well-known SIDs

segment.source: The values of certain SIDs are constant across all systems.
segment.target: The values of certain SIDs are constant across all systems.

segment.source: They are created when the operating system or domain is installed.
segment.target: They are created when the operating system or domain is installed.

segment.source: They are called well-known SIDs because they identify generic users or generic groups.
segment.target: They are called well-known SIDs because they identify generic users or generic groups.

segment.source: There are universal well-known SIDs that are meaningful on all secure systems that use this security model, including operating systems other than Windows.
segment.target: There are universal well-known SIDs that are meaningful on all secure systems that use this security model, including operating systems other than Windows.

segment.source: In addition, there are well-known SIDs that are meaningful only on Windows operating systems.
segment.target: In addition, there are well-known SIDs that are meaningful only on Windows operating systems.

segment.source: The following table lists the universal well-known SIDs.
segment.target: The following table lists the universal well-known SIDs.

segment.source: Value
segment.target: Value

segment.source: Universal Well-Known SID
segment.target: Universal Well-Known SID

segment.source: Identifies
segment.target: Identifies

segment.source: Null SID
segment.target: Null SID

segment.source: A group with no members.
segment.target: A group with no members.

segment.source: This is often used when a SID value is not known.
segment.target: This is often used when a SID value is not known.

segment.source: World
segment.target: World

segment.source: A group that includes all users.
segment.target: A group that includes all users.

segment.source: Local
segment.target: Local

segment.source: Users who log on to terminals that are locally (physically) connected to the system.
segment.target: Users who log on to terminals that are locally (physically) connected to the system.

segment.source: Console Logon
segment.target: Console Logon

segment.source: A group that includes users who are logged on to the physical console.
segment.target: A group that includes users who are logged on to the physical console.

segment.source: Creator Owner ID
segment.target: Creator Owner ID

segment.source: A security identifier to be replaced by the security identifier of the user who created a new object.
segment.target: A security identifier to be replaced by the security identifier of the user who created a new object.

segment.source: This SID is used in inheritable ACEs.
segment.target: This SID is used in inheritable ACEs.

segment.source: Creator Group ID
segment.target: Creator Group ID

segment.source: A security identifier to be replaced by the primary-group SID of the user who created a new object.
segment.target: A security identifier to be replaced by the primary-group SID of the user who created a new object.

segment.source: Use this SID in inheritable ACEs.
segment.target: Use this SID in inheritable ACEs.

segment.source: Creator Owner Server
segment.target: Creator Owner Server

segment.source: Creator Group Server
segment.target: Creator Group Server

segment.source: Owner Rights
segment.target: Owner Rights

segment.source: A group that represents the current owner of the object.
segment.target: A group that represents the current owner of the object.

segment.source: When an ACE that carries this SID is applied to an object, the system ignores the implicit READ_CONTROL and WRITE_DAC permissions for the object owner.
segment.target: When an ACE that carries this SID is applied to an object, the system ignores the implicit READ_CONTROL and WRITE_DAC permissions for the object owner.

segment.source: Non-unique Authority
segment.target: Non-unique Authority

segment.source: A SID that represents an identifier authority.
segment.target: A SID that represents an identifier authority.

segment.source: NT Authority
segment.target: NT Authority

segment.source: A SID that represents an identifier authority.
segment.target: A SID that represents an identifier authority.

segment.source: All Services
segment.target: All Services

segment.source: A group that includes all service processes configured on the system.
segment.target: A group that includes all service processes configured on the system.

segment.source: Membership is controlled by the operating system.
segment.target: Membership is controlled by the operating system.

segment.source: The following table lists the predefined identifier authority constants.
segment.target: The following table lists the predefined identifier authority constants.

segment.source: The first four values are used with universal well-known SIDs, and the last value is used with well-known SIDs in Windows operating systems designated in the Applies To list.
segment.target: The first four values are used with universal well-known SIDs, and the last value is used with well-known SIDs in Windows operating systems designated in the Applies To list.

segment.source: Identifier Authority
segment.target: Identifier Authority

segment.source: Value
segment.target: Value

segment.source: SID String Prefix
segment.target: SID String Prefix

segment.source: SECURITY_NULL_SID_AUTHORITY
segment.target: SECURITY_NULL_SID_AUTHORITY

segment.source: SECURITY_WORLD_SID_AUTHORITY
segment.target: SECURITY_WORLD_SID_AUTHORITY

segment.source: SECURITY_LOCAL_SID_AUTHORITY
segment.target: SECURITY_LOCAL_SID_AUTHORITY

segment.source: SECURITY_CREATOR_SID_AUTHORITY
segment.target: SECURITY_CREATOR_SID_AUTHORITY

segment.source: The following RID values are used with universal well-known SIDs.
segment.target: The following RID values are used with universal well-known SIDs.

segment.source: The Identifier authority column shows the prefix of the identifier authority with which you can combine the RID to create a universal well-known SID.
segment.target: The Identifier authority column shows the prefix of the identifier authority with which you can combine the RID to create a universal well-known SID.

segment.source: Relative Identifier Authority
segment.target: Relative Identifier Authority

segment.source: Value
segment.target: Value

segment.source: Identifier Authority
segment.target: Identifier Authority

segment.source: SECURITY_NULL_RID
segment.target: SECURITY_NULL_RID

segment.source: SECURITY_WORLD_RID
segment.target: SECURITY_WORLD_RID

segment.source: SECURITY_LOCAL_RID
segment.target: SECURITY_LOCAL_RID

segment.source: SECURITY_CREATOR_OWNER_RID
segment.target: SECURITY_CREATOR_OWNER_RID

segment.source: SECURITY_CREATOR_GROUP_RID
segment.target: SECURITY_CREATOR_GROUP_RID

segment.source: The SECURITYNTAUTHORITY (S-1-5) predefined identifier authority produces SIDs that are not universal and are meaningful only in installations of the Windows operating systems that are designated in the Applies To list at the beginning of this topic.
segment.target: The SECURITYNTAUTHORITY (S-1-5) predefined identifier authority produces SIDs that are not universal and are meaningful only in installations of the Windows operating systems that are designated in the Applies To list at the beginning of this topic.

segment.source: The following table lists the well-known SIDs.
segment.target: The following table lists the well-known SIDs.

segment.source: SID
segment.target: SID

segment.source: Display Name
segment.target: Display Name

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Dialup
segment.target: Dialup

segment.source: A group that includes all users who are logged on to the system by means of a dial-up connection.
segment.target: A group that includes all users who are logged on to the system by means of a dial-up connection.

segment.source: Local account
segment.target: Local account

segment.source: You can use this SID when restricting network logon to local accounts instead of "administrator" or equivalent.
segment.target: You can use this SID when restricting network logon to local accounts instead of "administrator" or equivalent.

segment.source: This SID can be effective in blocking network logon for local users and groups by account type regardless of what they are actually named.
segment.target: This SID can be effective in blocking network logon for local users and groups by account type regardless of what they are actually named.

segment.source: Local account and member of Administrators group
segment.target: Local account and member of Administrators group

segment.source: You can use this SID when restricting network logon to local accounts instead of "administrator" or equivalent.
segment.target: You can use this SID when restricting network logon to local accounts instead of "administrator" or equivalent.

segment.source: This SID can be effective in blocking network logon for local users and groups by account type regardless of what they are actually named.
segment.target: This SID can be effective in blocking network logon for local users and groups by account type regardless of what they are actually named.

segment.source: Network
segment.target: Network

segment.source: A group that includes all users who are logged on by means of a network connection.
segment.target: A group that includes all users who are logged on by means of a network connection.

segment.source: Access tokens for interactive users do not contain the Network SID.
segment.target: Access tokens for interactive users do not contain the Network SID.

segment.source: Batch
segment.target: Batch

segment.source: A group that includes all users who have logged on by means of a batch queue facility, such as task scheduler jobs.
segment.target: A group that includes all users who have logged on by means of a batch queue facility, such as task scheduler jobs.

segment.source: Interactive
segment.target: Interactive

segment.source: A group that includes all users who log on interactively.
segment.target: A group that includes all users who log on interactively.

segment.source: A user can start an interactive logon session by logging on directly at the keyboard, by opening a Remote Desktop Services connection from a remote computer, or by using a remote shell such as Telnet.
segment.target: A user can start an interactive logon session by logging on directly at the keyboard, by opening a Remote Desktop Services connection from a remote computer, or by using a remote shell such as Telnet.

segment.source: In each case, the user's access token contains the Interactive SID.
segment.target: In each case, the user's access token contains the Interactive SID.

segment.source: If the user signs in by using a Remote Desktop Services connection, the user's access token also contains the Remote Interactive Logon SID.
segment.target: If the user signs in by using a Remote Desktop Services connection, the user's access token also contains the Remote Interactive Logon SID.

segment.source: Logon Session
segment.target: Logon Session

segment.source: The X and Y values for these SIDs uniquely identify a particular logon session.
segment.target: The X and Y values for these SIDs uniquely identify a particular logon session.

segment.source: Service
segment.target: Service

segment.source: A group that includes all security principals that have signed in as a service.
segment.target: A group that includes all security principals that have signed in as a service.

segment.source: Anonymous Logon
segment.target: Anonymous Logon

segment.source: A user who has connected to the computer without supplying a user name and password.
segment.target: A user who has connected to the computer without supplying a user name and password.

segment.source: The Anonymous Logon identity is different from the identity that is used by Internet Information Services (IIS) for anonymous web access.
segment.target: The Anonymous Logon identity is different from the identity that is used by Internet Information Services (IIS) for anonymous web access.

segment.source: IIS uses an actual account—by default, IUSR_ ComputerName , for anonymous access to resources on a website.
segment.target: IIS uses an actual account—by default, IUSR_ ComputerName , for anonymous access to resources on a website.

segment.source: Strictly speaking, such access is not anonymous because the security principal is known even though unidentified people are using the account.
segment.target: Strictly speaking, such access is not anonymous because the security principal is known even though unidentified people are using the account.

segment.source: IUSR_ ComputerName (or whatever you name the account) has a password, and IIS logs on the account when the service starts.
segment.target: IUSR_ ComputerName (or whatever you name the account) has a password, and IIS logs on the account when the service starts.

segment.source: As a result, the IIS "anonymous" user is a member of Authenticated Users but Anonymous Logon is not.
segment.target: As a result, the IIS "anonymous" user is a member of Authenticated Users but Anonymous Logon is not.

segment.source: Proxy
segment.target: Proxy

segment.source: Does not currently apply: this SID is not used.
segment.target: Does not currently apply: this SID is not used.

segment.source: Enterprise Domain Controllers
segment.target: Enterprise Domain Controllers

segment.source: A group that includes all domain controllers in a forest of domains.
segment.target: A group that includes all domain controllers in a forest of domains.

segment.source: Self
segment.target: Self

segment.source: A placeholder in an ACE for a user, group, or computer object in Active Directory.
segment.target: A placeholder in an ACE for a user, group, or computer object in Active Directory.

segment.source: When you grant permissions to Self, you grant them to the security principal that is represented by the object.
segment.target: When you grant permissions to Self, you grant them to the security principal that is represented by the object.

segment.source: During an access check, the operating system replaces the SID for Self with the SID for the security principal that is represented by the object.
segment.target: During an access check, the operating system replaces the SID for Self with the SID for the security principal that is represented by the object.

segment.source: Authenticated Users
segment.target: Authenticated Users

segment.source: A group that includes all users and computers with identities that have been authenticated.
segment.target: A group that includes all users and computers with identities that have been authenticated.

segment.source: Authenticated Users does not include Guest even if the Guest account has a password.
segment.target: Authenticated Users does not include Guest even if the Guest account has a password.

segment.source: This group includes authenticated security principals from any trusted domain, not only the current domain.
segment.target: This group includes authenticated security principals from any trusted domain, not only the current domain.

segment.source: Restricted Code
segment.target: Restricted Code

segment.source: An identity that is used by a process that is running in a restricted security context.
segment.target: An identity that is used by a process that is running in a restricted security context.

segment.source: In Windows and Windows Server operating systems, a software restriction policy can assign one of three security levels to code: unrestricted, restricted, or disallowed.
segment.target: In Windows and Windows Server operating systems, a software restriction policy can assign one of three security levels to code: unrestricted, restricted, or disallowed.

segment.source: When code runs at the restricted security level, the Restricted SID is added to the user's access token.
segment.target: When code runs at the restricted security level, the Restricted SID is added to the user's access token.

segment.source: Terminal Server User
segment.target: Terminal Server User

segment.source: A group that includes all users who sign in to a server with Remote Desktop Services enabled.
segment.target: A group that includes all users who sign in to a server with Remote Desktop Services enabled.

segment.source: Remote Interactive Logon
segment.target: Remote Interactive Logon

segment.source: A group that includes all users who log on to the computer by using a remote desktop connection.
segment.target: A group that includes all users who log on to the computer by using a remote desktop connection.

segment.source: This group is a subset of the Interactive group.
segment.target: This group is a subset of the Interactive group.

segment.source: Access tokens that contain the Remote Interactive Logon SID also contain the Interactive SID.
segment.target: Access tokens that contain the Remote Interactive Logon SID also contain the Interactive SID.

segment.source: This Organization
segment.target: This Organization

segment.source: A group that includes all users from the same organization.
segment.target: A group that includes all users from the same organization.

segment.source: Only included with Active Directory accounts and only added by a domain controller.
segment.target: Only included with Active Directory accounts and only added by a domain controller.

segment.source: IIS_USRS
segment.target: IIS_USRS

segment.source: An account that is used by the default Internet Information Services (IIS) user.
segment.target: An account that is used by the default Internet Information Services (IIS) user.

segment.source: System (or LocalSystem)
segment.target: System (or LocalSystem)

segment.source: An identity that is used locally by the operating system and by services that are configured to sign in as LocalSystem.
segment.target: An identity that is used locally by the operating system and by services that are configured to sign in as LocalSystem.

segment.source: System is a hidden member of Administrators.
segment.target: System is a hidden member of Administrators.

segment.source: That is, any process running as System has the SID for the built-in Administrators group in its access token.
segment.target: That is, any process running as System has the SID for the built-in Administrators group in its access token.

segment.source: When a process that is running locally as System accesses network resources, it does so by using the computer's domain identity.
segment.target: When a process that is running locally as System accesses network resources, it does so by using the computer's domain identity.

segment.source: Its access token on the remote computer includes the SID for the local computer's domain account plus SIDs for security groups that the computer is a member of, such as Domain Computers and Authenticated Users.
segment.target: Its access token on the remote computer includes the SID for the local computer's domain account plus SIDs for security groups that the computer is a member of, such as Domain Computers and Authenticated Users.

segment.source: NT Authority (LocalService)
segment.target: NT Authority (LocalService)

segment.source: An identity that is used by services that are local to the computer, have no need for extensive local access, and do not need authenticated network access.
segment.target: An identity that is used by services that are local to the computer, have no need for extensive local access, and do not need authenticated network access.

segment.source: Services that run as LocalService access local resources as ordinary users, and they access network resources as anonymous users.
segment.target: Services that run as LocalService access local resources as ordinary users, and they access network resources as anonymous users.

segment.source: As a result, a service that runs as LocalService has significantly less authority than a service that runs as LocalSystem locally and on the network.
segment.target: As a result, a service that runs as LocalService has significantly less authority than a service that runs as LocalSystem locally and on the network.

segment.source: Network Service
segment.target: Network Service

segment.source: An identity that is used by services that have no need for extensive local access but do need authenticated network access.
segment.target: An identity that is used by services that have no need for extensive local access but do need authenticated network access.

segment.source: Services running as NetworkService access local resources as ordinary users and access network resources by using the computer's identity.
segment.target: Services running as NetworkService access local resources as ordinary users and access network resources by using the computer's identity.

segment.source: As a result, a service that runs as NetworkService has the same network access as a service that runs as LocalSystem, but it has significantly reduced local access.
segment.target: As a result, a service that runs as NetworkService has the same network access as a service that runs as LocalSystem, but it has significantly reduced local access.

segment.source: S-1-5-domain-500
segment.target: S-1-5-domain-500

segment.source: Administrator
segment.target: Administrator

segment.source: A user account for the system administrator.
segment.target: A user account for the system administrator.

segment.source: Every computer has a local Administrator account and every domain has a domain Administrator account.
segment.target: Every computer has a local Administrator account and every domain has a domain Administrator account.

segment.source: The Administrator account is the first account created during operating system installation.
segment.target: The Administrator account is the first account created during operating system installation.

segment.source: The account cannot be deleted, disabled, or locked out, but it can be renamed.
segment.target: The account cannot be deleted, disabled, or locked out, but it can be renamed.

segment.source: By default, the Administrator account is a member of the Administrators group, and it cannot be removed from that group.
segment.target: By default, the Administrator account is a member of the Administrators group, and it cannot be removed from that group.

segment.source: S-1-5-domain-501
segment.target: S-1-5-domain-501

segment.source: Guest
segment.target: Guest

segment.source: A user account for people who do not have individual accounts.
segment.target: A user account for people who do not have individual accounts.

segment.source: Every computer has a local Guest account, and every domain has a domain Guest account.
segment.target: Every computer has a local Guest account, and every domain has a domain Guest account.

segment.source: By default, Guest is a member of the Everyone and the Guests groups.
segment.target: By default, Guest is a member of the Everyone and the Guests groups.

segment.source: The domain Guest account is also a member of the Domain Guests and Domain Users groups.
segment.target: The domain Guest account is also a member of the Domain Guests and Domain Users groups.

segment.source: Unlike Anonymous Logon, Guest is a real account, and it can be used to log on interactively.
segment.target: Unlike Anonymous Logon, Guest is a real account, and it can be used to log on interactively.

segment.source: The Guest account does not require a password, but it can have one.
segment.target: The Guest account does not require a password, but it can have one.

segment.source: S-1-5-domain-502
segment.target: S-1-5-domain-502

segment.source: krbtgt
segment.target: krbtgt

segment.source: A user account that is used by the Key Distribution Center (KDC) service.
segment.target: A user account that is used by the Key Distribution Center (KDC) service.

segment.source: The account exists only on domain controllers.
segment.target: The account exists only on domain controllers.

segment.source: S-1-5-domain-512
segment.target: S-1-5-domain-512

segment.source: Domain Admins
segment.target: Domain Admins

segment.source: A global group with members that are authorized to administer the domain.
segment.target: A global group with members that are authorized to administer the domain.

segment.source: By default, the Domain Admins group is a member of the Administrators group on all computers that have joined the domain, including domain controllers.
segment.target: By default, the Domain Admins group is a member of the Administrators group on all computers that have joined the domain, including domain controllers.

segment.source: Domain Admins is the default owner of any object that is created in the domain's Active Directory by any member of the group.
segment.target: Domain Admins is the default owner of any object that is created in the domain's Active Directory by any member of the group.

segment.source: If members of the group create other objects, such as files, the default owner is the Administrators group.
segment.target: If members of the group create other objects, such as files, the default owner is the Administrators group.

segment.source: S-1-5-domain-513
segment.target: S-1-5-domain-513

segment.source: Domain Users
segment.target: Domain Users

segment.source: A global group that includes all users in a domain.
segment.target: A global group that includes all users in a domain.

segment.source: When you create a new User object in Active Directory, the user is automatically added to this group.
segment.target: When you create a new User object in Active Directory, the user is automatically added to this group.

segment.source: S-1-5-domain-514
segment.target: S-1-5-domain-514

segment.source: Domain Guests
segment.target: Domain Guests

segment.source: A global group, which by default, has only one member: the domain's built-in Guest account.
segment.target: A global group, which by default, has only one member: the domain's built-in Guest account.

segment.source: S-1-5-domain-515
segment.target: S-1-5-domain-515

segment.source: Domain Computers
segment.target: Domain Computers

segment.source: A global group that includes all computers that have joined the domain, excluding domain controllers.
segment.target: A global group that includes all computers that have joined the domain, excluding domain controllers.

segment.source: S-1-5-domain-516
segment.target: S-1-5-domain-516

segment.source: Domain Controllers
segment.target: Domain Controllers

segment.source: A global group that includes all domain controllers in the domain.
segment.target: A global group that includes all domain controllers in the domain.

segment.source: New domain controllers are added to this group automatically.
segment.target: New domain controllers are added to this group automatically.

segment.source: S-1-5-domain-517
segment.target: S-1-5-domain-517

segment.source: Cert Publishers
segment.target: Cert Publishers

segment.source: A global group that includes all computers that host an enterprise certification authority.
segment.target: A global group that includes all computers that host an enterprise certification authority.

segment.source: Cert Publishers are authorized to publish certificates for User objects in Active Directory.
segment.target: Cert Publishers are authorized to publish certificates for User objects in Active Directory.

segment.source: S-1-5-root domain-518
segment.target: S-1-5-root domain-518

segment.source: Schema Admins
segment.target: Schema Admins

segment.source: A group that exists only in the forest root domain.
segment.target: A group that exists only in the forest root domain.

segment.source: It is a universal group if the domain is in native mode, and it is a global group if the domain is in mixed mode.
segment.target: It is a universal group if the domain is in native mode, and it is a global group if the domain is in mixed mode.

segment.source: The Schema Admins group is authorized to make schema changes in Active Directory.
segment.target: The Schema Admins group is authorized to make schema changes in Active Directory.

segment.source: By default, the only member of the group is the Administrator account for the forest root domain.
segment.target: By default, the only member of the group is the Administrator account for the forest root domain.

segment.source: S-1-5-root domain-519
segment.target: S-1-5-root domain-519

segment.source: Enterprise Admins
segment.target: Enterprise Admins

segment.source: A group that exists only in the forest root domain.
segment.target: A group that exists only in the forest root domain.

segment.source: It is a universal group if the domain is in native mode, and it is a global group if the domain is in mixed mode.
segment.target: It is a universal group if the domain is in native mode, and it is a global group if the domain is in mixed mode.

segment.source: The Enterprise Admins group is authorized to make changes to the forest infrastructure, such as adding child domains, configuring sites, authorizing DHCP servers, and installing enterprise certification authorities.
segment.target: The Enterprise Admins group is authorized to make changes to the forest infrastructure, such as adding child domains, configuring sites, authorizing DHCP servers, and installing enterprise certification authorities.

segment.source: By default, the only member of Enterprise Admins is the Administrator account for the forest root domain.
segment.target: By default, the only member of Enterprise Admins is the Administrator account for the forest root domain.

segment.source: The group is a default member of every Domain Admins group in the forest.
segment.target: The group is a default member of every Domain Admins group in the forest.

segment.source: S-1-5-domain-520
segment.target: S-1-5-domain-520

segment.source: Group Policy Creator Owners
segment.target: Group Policy Creator Owners

segment.source: A global group that is authorized to create new Group Policy Objects in Active Directory.
segment.target: A global group that is authorized to create new Group Policy Objects in Active Directory.

segment.source: By default, the only member of the group is Administrator.
segment.target: By default, the only member of the group is Administrator.

segment.source: Objects that are created by members of Group Policy Creator Owners are owned by the individual user who creates them.
segment.target: Objects that are created by members of Group Policy Creator Owners are owned by the individual user who creates them.

segment.source: In this way, the Group Policy Creator Owners group is unlike other administrative groups (such as Administrators and Domain Admins).
segment.target: In this way, the Group Policy Creator Owners group is unlike other administrative groups (such as Administrators and Domain Admins).

segment.source: Objects that are created by members of these groups are owned by the group rather than by the individual.
segment.target: Objects that are created by members of these groups are owned by the group rather than by the individual.

segment.source: S-1-5-domain-553
segment.target: S-1-5-domain-553

segment.source: RAS and IAS Servers
segment.target: RAS and IAS Servers

segment.source: A local domain group.
segment.target: A local domain group.

segment.source: By default, this group has no members.
segment.target: By default, this group has no members.

segment.source: Computers that are running the Routing and Remote Access service are added to the group automatically.
segment.target: Computers that are running the Routing and Remote Access service are added to the group automatically.

segment.source: Members of this group have access to certain properties of User objects, such as Read Account Restrictions, Read Logon Information, and Read Remote Access Information.
segment.target: Members of this group have access to certain properties of User objects, such as Read Account Restrictions, Read Logon Information, and Read Remote Access Information.

segment.source: Administrators
segment.target: Administrators

segment.source: A built-in group.
segment.target: A built-in group.

segment.source: After the initial installation of the operating system, the only member of the group is the Administrator account.
segment.target: After the initial installation of the operating system, the only member of the group is the Administrator account.

segment.source: When a computer joins a domain, the Domain Admins group is added to the Administrators group.
segment.target: When a computer joins a domain, the Domain Admins group is added to the Administrators group.

segment.source: When a server becomes a domain controller, the Enterprise Admins group also is added to the Administrators group.
segment.target: When a server becomes a domain controller, the Enterprise Admins group also is added to the Administrators group.

segment.source: Users
segment.target: Users

segment.source: A built-in group.
segment.target: A built-in group.

segment.source: After the initial installation of the operating system, the only member is the Authenticated Users group.
segment.target: After the initial installation of the operating system, the only member is the Authenticated Users group.

segment.source: Guests
segment.target: Guests

segment.source: A built-in group.
segment.target: A built-in group.

segment.source: By default, the only member is the Guest account.
segment.target: By default, the only member is the Guest account.

segment.source: The Guests group allows occasional or one-time users to log on with limited privileges to a computer's built-in Guest account.
segment.target: The Guests group allows occasional or one-time users to log on with limited privileges to a computer's built-in Guest account.

segment.source: Power Users
segment.target: Power Users

segment.source: A built-in group.
segment.target: A built-in group.

segment.source: By default, the group has no members.
segment.target: By default, the group has no members.

segment.source: Power users can create local users and groups; modify and delete accounts that they have created; and remove users from the Power Users, Users, and Guests groups.
segment.target: Power users can create local users and groups; modify and delete accounts that they have created; and remove users from the Power Users, Users, and Guests groups.

segment.source: Power users also can install programs; create, manage, and delete local printers; and create and delete file shares.
segment.target: Power users also can install programs; create, manage, and delete local printers; and create and delete file shares.

segment.source: Account Operators
segment.target: Account Operators

segment.source: A built-in group that exists only on domain controllers.
segment.target: A built-in group that exists only on domain controllers.

segment.source: By default, the group has no members.
segment.target: By default, the group has no members.

segment.source: By default, Account Operators have permission to create, modify, and delete accounts for users, groups, and computers in all containers and organizational units of Active Directory except the Builtin container and the Domain Controllers OU.
segment.target: By default, Account Operators have permission to create, modify, and delete accounts for users, groups, and computers in all containers and organizational units of Active Directory except the Builtin container and the Domain Controllers OU.

segment.source: Account Operators do not have permission to modify the Administrators and Domain Admins groups, nor do they have permission to modify the accounts for members of those groups.
segment.target: Account Operators do not have permission to modify the Administrators and Domain Admins groups, nor do they have permission to modify the accounts for members of those groups.

segment.source: Server Operators
segment.target: Server Operators

segment.source: Description: A built-in group that exists only on domain controllers.
segment.target: Description: A built-in group that exists only on domain controllers.

segment.source: By default, the group has no members.
segment.target: By default, the group has no members.

segment.source: Server Operators can log on to a server interactively; create and delete network shares; start and stop services; back up and restore files; format the hard disk of the computer; and shut down the computer.
segment.target: Server Operators can log on to a server interactively; create and delete network shares; start and stop services; back up and restore files; format the hard disk of the computer; and shut down the computer.

segment.source: Print Operators
segment.target: Print Operators

segment.source: A built-in group that exists only on domain controllers.
segment.target: A built-in group that exists only on domain controllers.

segment.source: By default, the only member is the Domain Users group.
segment.target: By default, the only member is the Domain Users group.

segment.source: Print Operators can manage printers and document queues.
segment.target: Print Operators can manage printers and document queues.

segment.source: Backup Operators
segment.target: Backup Operators

segment.source: A built-in group.
segment.target: A built-in group.

segment.source: By default, the group has no members.
segment.target: By default, the group has no members.

segment.source: Backup Operators can back up and restore all files on a computer, regardless of the permissions that protect those files.
segment.target: Backup Operators can back up and restore all files on a computer, regardless of the permissions that protect those files.

segment.source: Backup Operators also can log on to the computer and shut it down.
segment.target: Backup Operators also can log on to the computer and shut it down.

segment.source: Replicators
segment.target: Replicators

segment.source: A built-in group that is used by the File Replication service on domain controllers.
segment.target: A built-in group that is used by the File Replication service on domain controllers.

segment.source: By default, the group has no members.
segment.target: By default, the group has no members.

segment.source: Do not add users to this group.
segment.target: Do not add users to this group.

segment.source: NTLM Authentication
segment.target: NTLM Authentication

segment.source: A SID that is used when the NTLM authentication package authenticated the client
segment.target: A SID that is used when the NTLM authentication package authenticated the client

segment.source: SChannel Authentication
segment.target: SChannel Authentication

segment.source: A SID that is used when the SChannel authentication package authenticated the client.
segment.target: A SID that is used when the SChannel authentication package authenticated the client.

segment.source: Digest Authentication
segment.target: Digest Authentication

segment.source: A SID that is used when the Digest authentication package authenticated the client.
segment.target: A SID that is used when the Digest authentication package authenticated the client.

segment.source: NT Service
segment.target: NT Service

segment.source: A SID that is used as an NT Service account prefix.
segment.target: A SID that is used as an NT Service account prefix.

segment.source: All Services
segment.target: All Services

segment.source: A group that includes all service processes that are configured on the system.
segment.target: A group that includes all service processes that are configured on the system.

segment.source: Membership is controlled by the operating system.
segment.target: Membership is controlled by the operating system.

segment.source: SID S-1-5-80-0 equals NT SERVICES\ALL SERVICES.
segment.target: SID S-1-5-80-0 equals NT SERVICES\ALL SERVICES.

segment.source: This SID was introduced in Windows Server 2008 R2.
segment.target: This SID was introduced in Windows Server 2008 R2.

segment.source: NT VIRTUAL MACHINE\Virtual Machines
segment.target: NT VIRTUAL MACHINE\Virtual Machines

segment.source: A built-in group.
segment.target: A built-in group.

segment.source: The group is created when the Hyper-V role is installed.
segment.target: The group is created when the Hyper-V role is installed.

segment.source: Membership in the group is maintained by the Hyper-V Management Service (VMMS).
segment.target: Membership in the group is maintained by the Hyper-V Management Service (VMMS).

segment.source: This group requires the Create Symbolic Links right (SeCreateSymbolicLinkPrivilege), and also the Log on as a Service right (SeServiceLogonRight).
segment.target: This group requires the Create Symbolic Links right (SeCreateSymbolicLinkPrivilege), and also the Log on as a Service right (SeServiceLogonRight).

segment.source: Untrusted Mandatory Level
segment.target: Untrusted Mandatory Level

segment.source: A SID that represents an untrusted integrity level.
segment.target: A SID that represents an untrusted integrity level.

segment.source: Low Mandatory Level
segment.target: Low Mandatory Level

segment.source: A SID that represents a low integrity level.
segment.target: A SID that represents a low integrity level.

segment.source: Medium Mandatory Level
segment.target: Medium Mandatory Level

segment.source: This SID represents a medium integrity level.
segment.target: This SID represents a medium integrity level.

segment.source: Medium Plus Mandatory Level
segment.target: Medium Plus Mandatory Level

segment.source: A SID that represents a medium plus integrity level.
segment.target: A SID that represents a medium plus integrity level.

segment.source: High Mandatory Level
segment.target: High Mandatory Level

segment.source: A SID that represents a high integrity level.
segment.target: A SID that represents a high integrity level.

segment.source: System Mandatory Level
segment.target: System Mandatory Level

segment.source: A SID that represents a system integrity level.
segment.target: A SID that represents a system integrity level.

segment.source: Protected Process Mandatory Level
segment.target: Protected Process Mandatory Level

segment.source: A SID that represents a protected-process integrity level.
segment.target: A SID that represents a protected-process integrity level.

segment.source: Secure Process Mandatory Level
segment.target: Secure Process Mandatory Level

segment.source: A SID that represents a secure process integrity level.
segment.target: A SID that represents a secure process integrity level.

segment.source: The following RIDs are relative to each domain.
segment.target: The following RIDs are relative to each domain.

segment.source: RID
segment.target: RID

segment.source: Identifies
segment.target: Identifies

segment.source: DOMAIN_USER_RID_ADMIN
segment.target: DOMAIN_USER_RID_ADMIN

segment.source: The administrative user account in a domain.
segment.target: The administrative user account in a domain.

segment.source: DOMAIN_USER_RID_GUEST
segment.target: DOMAIN_USER_RID_GUEST

segment.source: The guest-user account in a domain.
segment.target: The guest-user account in a domain.

segment.source: Users who do not have an account can automatically sign in to this account.
segment.target: Users who do not have an account can automatically sign in to this account.

segment.source: DOMAIN_GROUP_RID_USERS
segment.target: DOMAIN_GROUP_RID_USERS

segment.source: A group that contains all user accounts in a domain.
segment.target: A group that contains all user accounts in a domain.

segment.source: All users are automatically added to this group.
segment.target: All users are automatically added to this group.

segment.source: DOMAIN_GROUP_RID_GUESTS
segment.target: DOMAIN_GROUP_RID_GUESTS

segment.source: The group Guest account in a domain.
segment.target: The group Guest account in a domain.

segment.source: DOMAIN_GROUP_RID_COMPUTERS
segment.target: DOMAIN_GROUP_RID_COMPUTERS

segment.source: The Domain Computer group.
segment.target: The Domain Computer group.

segment.source: All computers in the domain are members of this group.
segment.target: All computers in the domain are members of this group.

segment.source: DOMAIN_GROUP_RID_CONTROLLERS
segment.target: DOMAIN_GROUP_RID_CONTROLLERS

segment.source: The Domain Controller group.
segment.target: The Domain Controller group.

segment.source: All domain controllers in the domain are members of this group.
segment.target: All domain controllers in the domain are members of this group.

segment.source: DOMAIN_GROUP_RID_CERT_ADMINS
segment.target: DOMAIN_GROUP_RID_CERT_ADMINS

segment.source: The certificate publishers' group.
segment.target: The certificate publishers' group.
